awd_titl_txt: NeuroDataRR: Predicting intelligence from resting-state fMRI: parcellation, pipelines and models
awd_abstract_narration:
Individual differences in cognitive abilities ultimately derive from differences in brain function.  Recent studies have been able to predict, to some degree, individual differences in intelligence from the connectivity pattern among brain regions obtained at rest with functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI).  However, it remains unclear how reliable these findings are, how well they replicate, and to what extent they generalize to other samples.  These questions have also limited our understand of what it is in the neuroimaging data that drives these predictions; for example, are there specific brain regions, or specific ways that the data are processed that make a difference?  To address these questions this project will begin with a successful initial finding, predicting intelligence from rs-fMRI with a particular approach, in a large data set (the Human Connectome Project data, HCP).  Building from this initial finding, a series of research aims will then investigate how different kinds of analyses might yield different results, how statistically reliable the findings are, how well they replicate, and how they generalize to databases other than the HCP.  These findings will be high methodological value to all scientists working in this field and will also yield initial answers to important questions regarding the neural basis of intelligence. All work will use open-science practices including but not limited to pre-registration and data sharing of data and software.

This project capitalizes on recent success in predicting general intelligence (g) from resting-state fMRI (rs-fMRI) data in the Human Connectome Project dataset (HCP).  Its principal aims are to investigate the reliability, reproducibility, and generalizability of this finding. A first aim will quantify the effect of brain alignment, rs-fMRI denoising, brain parcellation, and model-learning strategy on the prediction of intelligence from rs-fMRI in the HCP.  The aim will quantify how choices at key intersections in this processing decision tree affect final prediction results. This investigation will provide a valuable inventory of possible processing pipelines, and the difference that different parameter choices make; aim to yield a single "best" combination of analytical choices; and explore which anatomical brain regions, and networks, can best predict intelligence.  A second aim will add graph-theoretical summary features and externally driven brain states to improve the prediction of intelligence in the HCP.   Do features derived from rs- or task-fMRI yield substantially better predictions? Do models built separately from each paradigm, and for different tasks, point to shared anatomical regions? Combining features from both paradigms, what is the best prediction we can obtain?  To investigate the generalizability of results obtained, the results will be replicated across three independent datasets: the Enhanced Nathan Kline Institute - Rockland Sample (NKI-RS; target 1000 participants, 6-85 year-olds), the NIH Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development dataset (ABCD; target 10,000 participants, 9-10 year-olds), and the Cambridge Center for Ageing and Neuroscience (Cam-CAN; 700 participants, 18-88 year-olds). These pre-registered studies will quantify how robust are the brain predictors of intelligence (to different subject samples, and different MRI acquisition methods).

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to use human neuroimaging (magnetic resonance imaging, MRI) data to predict individual differences in people's intelligence. We know that intelligence somehow arises from brain activity. By measuring brain activity, is it possible to predict, at least to some degree, somebody?s intelligence? How well can it be predicted?  Which parts of the brain are most predictive?  These questions would help us understand how intelligence is related to the brain, and how it might be related to other brain functions as well (such as personality, for instance). Our grant brought together undergraduate students, graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and faculty to tackle this topic. We proceeded in three steps.

First, we tried out a number of different methods.  For instance, it is well known that there are many different ways of analyzing MRI data.  Do these make a difference to how well one can predict intelligence? We chose as our dataset the data from the Human Connectome Project, an NIH-funded publicly available dataset from over 1000 healthy adults. We found that, as we had expected, the precise way in which the data are processed and analyzed indeed makes a difference to how accurately and reliably we could predict intelligence. This first step had broader utility in quantifying which processing steps make the most difference.

Second, we also tried out different ways of quantifying intelligence. The measure available was from Raven?s Progressive Matrices, a task where you see geometric shapes in a series, and you then have to choose one to complete the series (this kind of test is popular in online tests of intelligence, for instance). However, this test is relatively short and we expected it would have considerable measurement error.  An alternative approach was to estimate intelligence from combined performance across many different tasks (memory tasks, attention tasks, etc.), which were also available in our database.  Estimating intelligence from this alternative approach (using a hierarchical factor analysis) produced numbers that we were able to predict much more accurately from the MRI data.  This second part showed us that, in addition to paying attention to the MRI data, it is equally important to pay attention to the psychological data that one wishes to predict (intelligence, in our case).

Third, we worked to develop new techniques to relate the two types of data, MRI data and intelligence scores. Standard approaches use linear regression, but more sophisticated mathematical techniques can be imagined. We worked on one called ?causal feature learning?, which tried to cluster the MRI data and the scores on individual intelligence test items. This work is still very much in progress and so far not easily applied to actually predict intelligence. However, it remains an important future goal.

Finally, we were concerned about the generalizability of our findings. In our analyses, we put a portion of the data to the side, so that when we had built an analysis based on the remainder, we could test whether that same analysis would work on the held-out data. We were also fortunate to have two MRI datasets for each participant in our dataset, and we therefore tested if each of these two MRI datasets gave the same answer. An important future goal of this work, which we did not yet accomplish, is to test our present results on a completely new dataset (either by collecting new data ourselves, or obtaining another high-quality dataset, distinct from the Human Connectome Project and involving different participants). 

The importance of the above components lies in their integrated and comprehensive nature. Published work on predicting individual differences (of intelligence and other measures) from neuroimaging data is often piecemeal, and includes studies that likely do not replicate. The analysis tools we developed here are publicly available to other scientists, so that they can apply them to their own analysis of MRI data.
